comments.body:
Fancy indexes that should also produce the same result:

```
s[[2.5]]
s.ix[[2.5]]
s.loc[[2.5]]
```

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1538,1542 @@        result1 = s[1.0:3.0]
        result2 = s.ix[1.0:3.0]
        result3 = s.loc[1.0:3.0]
        assert_series_equal(result1, result2)
        assert_series_equal(result1, result3)

comments.body:
This might be a good place for a test like:

```
expected = Series([3, 0], index=Float64Index([5.0, 0.0]))
for fancy_idx in [[5.0, 0.0], [5, 0], np.array([5.0, 0.0]), np.array([5, 0])]:
    assert_series_equal(s[fancy_idx], expected)
    assert_series_equal(s.loc[fancy_idx], expected)
    assert_series_equal(s.ix[fancy_idx], expected)
```

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1556,1560 @@
        self.assert_(s[5.0] == s[5])

        # value not found (and no fallbacking at all)

@@ -1,1 +1576,1580 @@        result2 = s.loc[2.0:5.0]
        result3 = s.loc[2.0:5]
        result4 = s.loc[2.1:5]
        assert_series_equal(result1, result2)
        assert_series_equal(result1, result3)

@@ -1,1 +1593,1597 @@        result2 = s.ix[2.0:5.0]
        result3 = s.ix[2.0:5]
        result4 = s.ix[2.1:5]
        assert_series_equal(result1, result2)
        assert_series_equal(result1, result3)

comments.body:
....doh, and now I get this far into the diff I discover you did add some of these tests after all :-). Well, the above might be useful, I guess...

(Except for the one that assumes fancy indexing with an unrecognized index gives a KeyError, I didn't realize that the rule in pandas is for those to return nan. Oops again.)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1627,1631 @@        assert_series_equal(result1, result2)
        assert_series_equal(result1, result3)
        assert_series_equal(result1, Series([0.0,np.nan,np.nan],index=[0,1,2]))

        result1 = s.loc[[2.5, 5]]

comments.body: so don't you need to catch the warning here?
so the logic of this is that it's okay to do 'chained-ish' assignment on Series, but can't do fancy indexing on copies?
